Welcome
In a speech to the incomingfreshmen last Saturday,
Johns Hopkins new president Lincoln Gordon compared his own position to the positions of the
persons he was speaking to, referring to himself
as "a fellow freshman." Dr. Gordon comes to us
with a long and distinguished record of political
and academic activity; and if any faith can be
placed on the words of the Board of Trustees, he
is "the one man who had the precise talents we
felt were necessary to lead Johns Hopkins at this
critical point in its history."
The arrival of a new president in a university
as diverse and complex as Hopkins is bound to
elicit conjecture and comment from every area of
the campus, and what we have seen here in the last
two weeks is no exception. Some people feel he will
bring a long needed dynamism which they say has
been lacking for years, others infer he who allegedly
manipulated strings and attempted to overthrow a
facist power in Brazil will use many of the same
machinations here where student affairs are concerned.
We wish to underscore the fact that Dr. Gordon,
despite all the information he has skimmed from
talking to every administrator and professor at
Hopkins, is indeed a freshman. Never before has
he been in a position where a combination of tact
and honesty must be used to placate and appease
such diverse voices as the students', the faculty's,
the administration's and the trustees'. In his first
public speech before a segment of the student body
last week, Dr. Gordon used some unfortunate phrases•
about which not only students but even the BALTIMORE SUN showed concern.
In a recent NEWS LETTER interview with Dr.
Gordon (which will be printed in full in next week's
issue), the new president explained more fully and
more understandingly what he meant by the "aberration of the alienated" and the "aberration of
direct action." He also explained that by "constraints which must be enforced," he was not inferring that he plans to create new rules where
few ever existed, nor does he plan to begin an indiscrimanate purge of all persons who have ever
tried marijuana or other mild drugs.
We hope only that Dr. Gordon will peruse the
Hopkins scene and will talk to many more students
as well as others here before launching any new
policies involving students. We also hope that the new
president, who is seemingly honest and willing to
talk at length to anyone, will more carefully consider the connotations of what he says.
We welcome you, President Gordon, and best of
luck in a difficult job.
